subtitle: We have now released issue 3 of the New Thinking Allowed magazine.
Download it for free at newthinkingallowed.org.
New Thinking Allowed is a non-profit endeavor.
Your contributions to the New Thinking Allowed
Foundation make a meaningful difference in
our ability to produce new videos.
Thinking Allowed – conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be exploring the beat generation of poets.
My guest is Charles Upton.
His first two books of poetry, Panic Grass
in 1968 and Time Raid in 1969, were published
by City Lights in San Francisco, known for
publishing the works of the great beat poets.
He was regarded at the time – he was still
in his teens – as perhaps the youngest member
of the beat generation.
He subsequently left that world and became
engaged in metaphysics and the traditionalist
movement.
He is the author of many books that have been discussed previously on this channel.
They include Cracks in the Great Wall, UFOs and Traditional Metaphysics, The Science of
the Greater Jihad, Essays in Principial Psychology.
The System of the Antichrist, Truth and Falsehood in Postmodernism and the New Age.
Vectors of the Counter-Initiation, the
Course and Destiny of Inverted Spirituality.
The Way Forward for Perennialism after the Antinomianism of Frithjof Schuon.
The Alien Disclosure Deception, the Metaphysics
of Social Engineering and Dugin Against Dugan,
a traditionalist critique of the fourth political theory.
Charles is located in Lexington, Kentucky and now I'll switch over to the internet
video.
Welcome Charles.
It's a pleasure to be with you once again.
It's been, I think, a few months since we've been together.
I can't talk continuously for a year.
You know, I have to take a vacation.
And I know I didn't mention it in the introduction,
but I know you've been busy writing an autobiography.
I hope that our viewers will look for it because
our topic today, The Beat Generation, is based
on a lot of material from that autobiography.
Yeah, the autobiography is called, this is a line I stole from Lew Welch, it's called
Giving Myself Away.
That's from a sermon he said, How to Give Yourself Away, a sermon of gladness, which
he delivered at Glide Memorial Church in San Francisco at one point.
Then I basically have a thing on a chapter on the teaching of Lew Welch, which is also
embedded in the different people in The Beat
Generation that he introduced me to, you know,
Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Allen Ginsberg, Gary Snyder, those people.
My wife and I got, well, we were with a poetry
scene, we were basically with a poetry scene
until 1979, when we did our last public reading together.
I guess I did a couple in the next 20 years,
but you know, that's when, and because we
were invited to read at the Savoy Tivoli Cafe
with Allen Ginsberg and Lawrence Ferlinghetti
and Jack Hirschman and a bunch of the guys.
So once we did that, we said, well, let's put it where we're at, you know.
If you met Carlos Castaneda, which I did at
one point, Lew Welch, a Beat Generation poet
who was my mentor as a poet, introduced me once to Carlos Castaneda, I have evidence
that some of the techniques that he used, shamanic techniques that he talked about in
his book, Journey to Islam, might have actually
come from Lew Welch, or the other way around.
It's hard to say, but there is a definite, you know, similarity there.
During that period, I was beginning to get involved with, on the edge of things, with
a Tibetan Buddhist Vajrayana teacher, Chögyam
Trungpa, and Ginsberg was drawing a lot
of the hippies and the poets from, you know,
it's like people from his generation and from
a generation younger who was me in the direction
of Trungpa, you know, William Burroughs ended
up following Trungpa.
And so, you know, so I almost got there and then I said, no, no.
This story is told in a book by Tom Clark called The Great Naropa Poetry Wars, which
have to do with the time that Trungpa sent
his Vajra guards to seize the well-known poet
and translator W.S.
Merwin and strip him and his fiancé and haul
them before him at a drunken party because
they wanted to be alone.
The guru wants you, you got to go to see the guru,
they wouldn't do it, so they were disciplined.
So this, of course, created a big brouhaha in the whole world of Buddhism and poetry.
So the poet Ed Sanders, who was a member of the
New York band The Fuggs, if you can remember
that.
I do.
He was there and he started to do an investigation into what happened.
So Trungpa said, well, that's wonderful, why
don't you, you can do a class at my place,
which is Naropa Institute at this point, Naropa
University, and a class in investigative poetics
and we'll give you a space and you can investigate it.
Total, perfect co-optation, just sure,
investigate it, we'll provide you what you need.
Let's go back to when you were in high school.
You were writing poetry at the time, right
before you met Lew Welch, who became something
of a mentor to you.
What was your life like?
You're a teenager in high school, in a Catholic
high school in Marin County, where I also
lived.
So we have that in common.
We both spent many years in San Rafael.
Well, I was just, you know, I lived with my parents.
I didn't have a license yet, you know.
I forget exactly when I got it, it was earlier
than some people do nowadays, but yeah, starting
to wake up from basically not knowing who the
hell I was or what was going on, but suddenly
poetry started to happen and it just started to happen.
Some of it was, some of the stuff I wrote in high school was pretty good, you know,
but most of it was incomplete, obviously, juvenilia and all of that.
But my relationships had to do with these people I knew from school.
It's the Trumbly clan.
The Trumblies were basically, I knew them because their names started with T and my
name started with U, so we sat together, you know.
And there were these, I described them as sort of like, you know, a Seinfeld menage
of quirky character types, I believe I said,
something like that, but you know, that was
Bob, Bill was the oldest, Bob was my age,
two younger brothers, Doug and Dan, and then
there was this Irish neighbor, John Doyle,
who was a formidable comedian, you know, very
extremely suric about comedy and imposing
his power of comedy on everybody, but we sort
of thought of ourselves as wanting vaguely
to be like a literary generation, like a beat
generation or something, but we weren't that
serious except for me, you know, and the thing
is, I was the guy that believed in God and
believed in higher consciousness and believed
in, you know, and I was the space cadet and
they were, you know, like cynical ex-Catholic
Irish apostates, as I call them, you know,
who had, you know, humor was their stock and
trade.
They had a metaphysical humor, which went to various different levels and they were
just that, you know, basically, you would say
they followed James Joyce, whereas I followed
W.B. Yates. That was the difference between us. It was Bill Trumbly, who was hungover
one morning and said, well, I've been going
to this class at the College of Marine where
this guy named Lew Welch, you know, a beat generation poet apparently, and so I'm too
hungover to go. Why don't you go in my place?
So that's how I met Lew Welch and, well, talk
about a life-changing thing and, you know,
and quickly, quickly, Lew Welch was a serious
alcoholic and like a number of the beat generation
guys, he was getting his second wind and suddenly
a much larger audience during the Hippy counterculture.
I mean, both he and Gary Snyder were writing
manifestos to be published in the San Francisco
Oracle and things like that, you know, underground
newspaper. You know, this is what the young should be thinking about and this is how we
can navigate these times. It was really attempting
to help, not imposing any ideology, but attempting
to make sense out of the huge changes that were going on. So anyway, and a few years
later he committed suicide up at Gary Snyder's
place, kit-kid-dizzy, near Nevada City in the
Sierra Foothills, but he was transmitting, you know, he sort of knew that he was not
long for this world. He committed suicide at 43 and this had been, you know, in the
back of his mind for most of his life and, you know, he was getting, he tried to, you
know, kick the bottle and he couldn't do it. And he just said to me once, I don't
want to end up to be a stumble bump, you know,
whino in the street, you know. So, you know,
he would rather go out at the height of his powers, which he did it. I mean, you know,
so very, he had some spiritual stuff to transmit
to me and he had some poetic stuff to transmit,
you know, and he transmitted them so deeply
and it's such a receptive period of my life.
I've been spending the rest of my life working
on them, translating them, refining. I finally
came up with the spiritual exercises of Lew Welch, essays
in perceptual Buddhism, which I've taken from various
of his poems, they're exercise. And I think they constitute or could be used as a new
approach to Zen Buddhism. Now, with Zen Buddhism,
you have two things. You have two schools.
There's the Soto school and the Rinzai school.
Rinzai school works with koans. You're given
a question that can't be answered in any simple, rational way. It's impossible. So,
the only way you can answer it is to get beyond
the need to make that kind of sense out of
things and just respond from your wholeness to it. Whatever you happen to say, that's
the right answer. Whereas if you say, hmm,
what is the sound of one hand clapping? Maybe
it's like this, right? No? Oh, no, that's not it. The other one is just sit. Soto
Zen. If you sit, you're the Buddha. Just sit,
be the Buddha. That's that. And of course
there's much more to it. But that's the basic
thing. Both of these things have to do with
you. Release the attachment and tendency of your mind to attach to ideas and recognize
the Buddha nature within yourself. But both of them leave the world out. And the world
is there too. The world is part of the whole
thing. If all things have the Buddha nature,
then so do the rocks and the trees and the cars and everything else. So you've got to
include the world. And perhaps the closest
thing to including the world has been something
like the Kendo tradition, the tradition of the samurai, when it's looked at from
a Zen perspective. Because you're dealing
with situations that come at you and you have
to deal with them. But Lew was basically doing
things like, what would the world look like
if I was already enlightened? If I look at it
that way, maybe that'll help me get enlightened.
And so very happily, very recently, I was finally able to make a gift of my rendition
of his exercises to Peter Coyote, who was a friend of Lew's. And I didn't know him
during the time I knew Lew. I knew him a little
later when I was working with Homeless, because
we were looking for all the celebrities we
could get. And so we made a little connection
with Peter Coyote. So luckily, Peter Coyote
by now is a Zen Roshi. I don't know how long
he was practicing Zen, but he finally took orders of whatever you call it in Zen, and
now he's an official teacher. So I said, well,
here's Lew Welch's teachings. The teachings,
for example, like this. When I first met Lew Welch at the College of Marina, it was
a little landscaped garden out in the campus.
I think buildings have been built there since,
but there's space. There were a few redwood trees, a little redwood grove, and a little
place to sit. And there was nobody there but
me and Lew Welch and Sister Mary Norbert Körte,
who was a... She just died recently. She was
a Dominican nun of the same nuns who taught
me in San Rafael Catholic School, but she was
a poet and a very fine poet. And she was on
the way to leaving the order, leaving the
church. Like the other guy that did that was
Brother Antoninus William Everson, who was a poet,
who was a Dominican friar, Dominican brother.
And I met him once, too, because a colleague of
his was Brother Christopher, one of my teachers
in high school. So I was getting to be a poet,
so he said, well, why don't you? You need to meet
Brother Antoninus. So I met him once. It was an
interesting connection. But Brother Antoninus,
basically, like a lot of the poets, he became
a shaman or figured he was a shaman. I'm not
sure about that. I always say if you're starting
to fail as a poet, you'll always claim to be a
shaman. But I don't know. But that was there,
though, because Lew did introduce me to Carlos
Castaneda. So anyway... And Sister Mary Norbert
just died. I suddenly... I was writing the story
of her and I said, wait a minute, I gotta talk
to her. I haven't talked to her in years. I was
following where she was. Some place in Northern
California, she spent many, many, many years of
her life trying to save a single stand of first
growth redwoods. And she finally did, with some
help, I'm sure. And soon after that, she died.
And I was just trying to get through to her and
there was somebody who apparently was in touch
with her. I left a message and said, I really
have to talk to her. Never got back to me. And
then like a couple of months later, she died.
So I must have felt this was the last chance, but
I never got through. So anyway, we were sitting
there. And Lew Welch is, you know, a very unexpected kind of person.
Lew Welch appears in the movie Big Sur, but
very incorrectly portrayed. You know, in Big
Sur, he's this frenetic kind of guy dancing
around. Lew was not like that. Lew was doing
things like never ask why what, always ask what's
what. Observe, connect, and do. And that's the way
he presented, you know, he was the most concrete,
slow, deliberate, painstakingly simple, as I say.
Man, you know, this is, and he said, you know,
you can't build a poem out of anything but words,
just like you can't build a brick wall out of
anything but bricks. That was his demeanor. So
he said to us, he wasn't talking about poetry. He said,
okay, let's do a perception exercise. Look at those trees over there. Redwood trees.
Then we'll imagine that the trunks of the trees
are empty, empty spaces, and the spaces between
the trees are solid. You just look and you say,
huh, can I do that? And suddenly the world flips,
and oh, oh yeah. Okay. And he just did that. Okay.
And you think, well, that's an interesting thing,
but where is that going? Well, where it's going
is that's very much like Carlos Castaneda's,
some of his exercises in Journey to Islam, in which you're supposed to stop the world,
you know, shifting your perception. Then I realized
much, much later that what he was doing was an
extremely concrete presentation of the Buddhist doctrine from the Heart Sutra,
which says form is emptiness, emptiness is form.
Oh, so instead of just having those words that
go into your ear and that you think about, oh,
that's interesting form, but yeah, I could sort
of start thinking about it. He said, let's do it.
He was that concrete, and concreteness was his
main thing. He was brought perhaps the most
metaphysical of all The Beats, but he wasn't
an intellectual, I mean, he didn't do it intellectually, he did it existentially,
which is so rare. And that's something, he
didn't do it exactly the way it's done in Zen,
but it was the same impulse. You know, it's like
I remember Huston Smith, who's a friend of mine,
my wife's for some years, he talked about going
to study Zen in Japan. He was in the same class
with Gary Snyder, you know, and I guess the Zen
master gave him a koan, you know, and he said,
well, and he started to talk, well, that could be, and the Zen master says to him,
you have the philosopher disease, you know, and
Lew Welch did not want to get the philosopher
disease or pass it on to anyone, just, you know, sidestep that. So he did that.
You know, what's interesting about that is years
later, I was meditating with my eyes open in
Bristol Park, you know, Bristol Park in San
Rafael, and there's a Redwood Grove there as well,
and what he did happened. Again, the Redwood
trees became empty spaces and the spaces between
the Redwood trees became birch trees, just as
clear as a bell. And I was waiting to connect
with somebody from this neo-Hindu group called
Brahma Kumaris, which he had an office at the
Elbert building, which is where my father used to have his dental offices, and I was
waiting there, meditating, waiting for that,
and that's what happened. So I said, obviously,
Lew Welch planted a perceptual seed, which really got deep, you know, and it's like,
if that can happen to the world, if it can shift
like that, well, what is the world? It's not a
literal object. Again, on the other hand, it's
not just inside your mind. It's not a fantasy,
because you're seeing that happen, really happen out there. So it's neither,
oh, well, like Ronald Reagan said, you've
seen Redwood trees, no, it wasn't like that.
And that's all I know what that is. I've got a
name for it. It's a Redwood tree. Sure, sure.
No, I don't have to, you know, learn anything
more about that. I've got that. No, you don't
got that. It's always changing. You're not paying
attention, you know. And then the other thing is
that it's not just a fantasy in your mind. You
know, I see Redwood trees turning into birch trees
in my mind. No, it's really out there. So it's
a third thing. There's neither a literal object,
nor a simple reverie of your own. It's an
apparition. And this is what pretty much the
Buddhists, I mean, the Tibetan Buddhists are
talking about with things like the rainbow body.
You know, they're talking about the world and
yourself as apparitions, not as subjective
dreams, and nor not as literal objective, you
know, realities, objects, but as something else.
And so the apparitional quality of the world,
you know, if you can shift your perception,
you can get there. That is one of the approaches to the enlightened state.
So I think, you know, and it was all hidden
because, you know, he was a terrible alcoholic.
He committed suicide. You tend to say, oh,
well, I guess that didn't work out. You know,
what could he have to teach? Well, what I saw with the Beat Generation, these guys
were truly desperate. They knew that something
greater was real than 1950s U.S. culture could
tell them, or junior Christianity, or there was
something more. But how are they going to approach
they had no idea. It was all on the wing, you
know, drugs, travel, sex, booze, something.
Now, of course, that can all just be
self-indulgence and largely was too. But also,
make a break with consensus reality because the consensus reality of the 50s was crazy.
I mean, the United States had just won the biggest war in history. We were on top.
We were the most powerful nation in the world,
Russia, I don't know. We were the most powerful
nation. We were the richest. Everyone that a few
decades before was living hand to mouth in the
Depression suddenly could afford a car, two cars,
and a house. And the wife could stay home and
take care of the kids and make a paradise. And
the husband would go out and make enough money.
And whoa, we were in. We had made it. On the other
hand, there's this thing called nuclear weapons.
And now the Russians have got them. And so
that cognitive dissonance between the greatest
success and the most terrible threat, you know,
caused the people, a lot of the people of the
50s, just to freeze up and become extremely
weird and wooden. You hear some of the people
talking about nuclear weapons, for example, from
old 50s educational films or something. It's
crazy. So they knew something was profoundly wrong
in the American psyche and they were going to do
anything they could to, you know, because this
was the point. Consensus reality was so repressive
and so imbalanced and so crazy that it was
justified, one could argue, for a short time,
to do almost anything to break out of. The problem is once that was broken out,
I mean, the hippies flew in and they kept breaking it. Now it is so broken.
It is so chaotic. It is so crazy in the other
way. Kierkegaard has two really important, pieces
Søren Kierkegaard, the Danish philosopher, existentialist philosopher, has two
very important concepts. One is called despair of
necessity and the other one is called despair of
possibility. And this is coming from pretty much Aristotle. Aristotle was talking about
necessary being and possible being. Necessary
being is according to Aquinas, Thomas Aquinas,
St. Thomas Aquinas, identifiable with God because
only God must be. Everything else just might or
might not be and that is possible to be. But
he did an amazing thing with these concepts,
with these categories, where he looked at the alienated aspects of both of them.
Despair of necessity is, well, the way it is
going to have to be forever, it will never change,
you are stuck, you know, get used to it, suck it
up, that is that. That is despair of necessity.
Despair of possibility is anything is possible,
you know. But as my friend, Bill Trugway,
who introduced me or sent me first to Lew Welch
said, he dropped acid before me. I had not done
it yet. I said, what did you learn? What happened?
What did you learn from taking LSD? And he said,
I learned that everything is possible but nothing
is likely. And that is exactly what Kierkegaard
meant by despair of possibility. You know,
possibility, possibility. It is like that was
perfectly satirized in the Firesign Theater
comic, you know, LP, everything you know is wrong,
which, you know, the guy was "Happy" Harry Cox, I
guess his name is, could be, could be, you know.
But yes, possible, you know, and now, you know,
you say, well, it is wonderful. You have a thousand
channels to choose from. For the rest of my life,
I do not have time to choose from a thousand
channels. So this is very alienating. This is
not, if possibility is going to mean anything,
it has to be actualizable at one point, you
know. And if necessity is going to mean anything,
it cannot just be a terribly imposed deadening
oppression that comes perhaps from some
vindictive God that this is the way it is going
to have to be. It has to be, hey, this is real.
This is reliable. This is always going to be real.
This is always going to be there. And so you can
believe in it, and you can even praise it, you know. And God, or this necessary being,
will help you realize the possibilities, the ones
that are right for you, you know. So that is what
necessity and possibility are in the, you know,
unalienated form, but they have got alienating
forms. So what happened is we went into despair
of possibility in the worst way. Until we came to
postmodernism, which says that any voice, any
version of reality has an equal right to speak,
because we do not want to be, you know, tyrannical
and imperialistic with our paradigms. Every
paradigm has an equal right to speak. Even William Blake said anything possible to be
believed is an image of truth. Okay, nice. But
you cannot put them all on the same level. You
have to hierarchicalize them. Some things are
more important than others. The child, the baby is
drowning in the swimming pool, and you say, well,
I could save the baby, or I could finish my drink.
Hmm. They are of equal value. See, you cannot do
that. You must have a hierarchy of values and a
hierarchical, a psychological hierarchy of reality.
You have got to do that, or you are crazy in the
opposite way that people were in the fifties.
And we got just that crazy. And so finally,
you know, everything is equally true in postmodernism. And what did that turn into?
It flipped, and it became wokeism, which lays
down an inquisition that some words are not to
be used, some thoughts are not to be thought,
some, you know, some values are not to be called,
you know, valuable. This is no longer the old
liberalism that says, I will, I may not agree
with a thing that you say, but I will defend to
the death your right to say it, which is from
Voltaire. Postmodernism had gone too far in
the other direction. Whenever you go too far,
in some direction, the point comes where it flips. And it flipped. It really flipped.
So that is what came of the counter culture.
Let's go back, if we can, to your relationship
with Lew Welch. You knew he was an alcoholic.
He was, we now know, doomed to commit suicide
at the height of his powers only a few years
after you met him. Yet, I gather that you became
extremely close to him. Yeah. I mean, he was
tutoring me. He knew he had teachers. He didn't
know who to give them to. And suddenly I popped
him. He says, he's the one, I'm going to do it.
So he just, everything that he had come to learn that he thought was, you know,
useful and rather unique, he just imprinted on
me for, you know, about a year or something.
I would go over to his house with his common
law wife, Magda Clegg. Huey Lewis's mother,
by the way. That's who she was. And she died
recently. And, you know, he would teach me
poetry by reading. He would do magnificent readings of Yeats, of Burroughs, you know,
and just get it in my ear. I mean, he'd say,
now, try reading this. See if you can see,
let me hear you read this. Like, he had things
called passenger poems, because he used to be
a cabbie. And he would hear people get drunk
in the back of his cab and start yapping away.
And once in a while, he would hear something very
interesting. So he said, oh, it's a found poem.
There's one that goes, I didn't do it very well
at the time, but I've been working on it for the
past 50 years. I've got better, which is, he
picks up a nurse, sort of middle-aged nurse who,
you know, is undoubtedly in her cuffs. And that's
why she's, you know, calling a cab and something.
And she's just talking away. She says, oh, man, I don't like cats. I don't like cats.
Kittens are all right, I guess. You can love them when they're little,
like people. And then they grow up and take
advantage of you. How can you love them anymore?
Think of what's in that. You know, there's a
whole life, a whole destiny. And, you know,
and think of the compassion that can hear that.
You know, this, you know, woman has been probably
abused by her kids, you know. But you can't quite
admit it. She has to talk about cats instead.
And Lew said at one point, he says in one of his
poems, I cannot help them. I will not treat them.
So, you know, there was not the slightest desire to intervene, even on a very,
you know, informal personal level, you know, to
be helpful. But it was a compassion that went
deeper than that. Because, well, that's that.
That's the way, that's her dilemma. That's her
situation. And just expressing it like that.
So, he would teach me, you know, basically
how to recite. He would say that, okay, his
main teaching with poetry is, poetry is speech.
And what I understood is the way you do that in terms of reciting poetry
is you have to avoid two extremes. Because
he basically said, you know, just, you know,
use your native American speech and the way you
talk when you really mean something. And then
use it in a recital poem, you know, with that
voice. And so there are different ways. I mean,
you can go into one extreme like with Dylan
Thomas, you know. You know, Altarwise by owl
-light in the half-way house The gentleman lay
graveward with his furies; Abaddon in the hangnail
cracked from Adam, And, from his fork, a dog among the
fairies, The atlas-eater with a jaw for news, Bit out the
with to-morrows scream. Then, penny-eyed, that
gentlemen of wounds, Old cock from nowheres
and the heaven's egg, With bones unbuttoned to the half-way winds,
Hatched from the windy salvage on one leg, Scraped at my cradle in a
walking word That night of time under the
Christward shelter: I am the long world's gentlemen,
he said, And share my bed with Capricorn and
Cancer. which is interesting. But what he what
he believed in was something more like this. And
this is another found poem, which goes like this.
Never, never put the goddamn camera in the glove
compartment. I told you and told you never put
the goddamn camera in the glove compartment.
So what do you do? You put the goddamn camera
in the glove compartment and it's stolen. See?
Well, that's the way he believed. And you can
even use something like that to recite a very
musical poem, you know, because if the poem gets
too musical, it becomes flimsy, you know, whereas
the other thing, the other problem is just to be
clinical and have no emotion, you know, and
recite words like a computer or like a robot.
And what you want is, you know, genuine American
speech. So that's what he taught. And I realized
the two masters of that kind of poetry, that
kind of, you know, talking a poem are John Donne
and Frank Sinatra. Now, John Donne would say, well,
you have this poem, well known poem, you know,
go and catch a falling star, get the child a
mandrake root. And you can do it two different ways.
Two different ways. You know, I mean, one way,
if you go too much into the music of the rhyming
medium, which comes from Italian, essentially
from the sonnet form that came from Italian into
English, to, you know, go and catch a falling
star, get with child a mandrake root. Tell me
where all past years are or who cleft the
devil's foot. It's been go and catch a falling
star, get with child a mandrake root. Tell
me where all past years are or who cleft the
devil's foot. Teach me to hear mermaids singing
and to keep all envy's stinging and to find what
wind serves to advance an honest mind. That's the
way to read it, talk it. And that's the way he
wrote it. So his poems can be talked through and
beyond the rhyming medium. And then, you know,
Sinatra did exactly the same thing. He would talk
his songs. You know, Perry Connell, for example,
would croon, but he didn't croon. I listened the
other night to various versions of Sinatra singing
one for my baby and one more for the road. And as
he got older, when he was young, he was crooning
it. But by the time he was like, you know, late fifties or something, he was talking.
It was so much better, so much more evocative,
you know. So this is what Lew taught as a poet.
But beyond that, there were perception things. What he taught about words,
he said that, he said this, he said, only poets know that words don't mean anything.
Well, what's that? That's a koan, because, of
course, they sort of do, don't they? And, you know,
but so he didn't want us to get involved in the
world of words, where you're living perceptually
and conceptually inside of verbal definitions
of things. Where you look at a rock and you say,
that's a rock, I know what that is, it's a rock.
It was more, when he said, those who live in the
world, those who live in the world of words kill
us, who seek union with what goes on, whether I
look at it or not. So what he was seeking was union
with what went on, whether he looked at it or not,
which means something beyond subjectivity. It's
really there. And, but how do you unite with
something that you're not looking at? It's not
even in your consciousness, and yet somehow you're
united with it. You know, you're not paying
attention to it. It's not even something else,
yet you're not united with it. You know, I mean,
he was trying to find what's beyond subject and
object. So that was one, you know, freedom from
the world of words. And he would do that through,
for example, through riddles, which are an interesting way of playing with language.
He has a riddle in this poem, Wobbly Rock.
It's called Wobbly Rock is the name of the poem
that he wrote about a rock on the shore at Amur
Beach, California. And I've been there myself,
it's a huge, he says, it's a real rock, believe
this first, made of, you know, resting on actual
sand at the surf's edge of Amur Beach, California.
Like everything else I have, somebody else showed
it to me, and I found it by myself. I love that.
Like everything else I have, somebody else showed
it to me, and I found it by myself. Hard, common
stone, the size of the largest haystack it moves
were hit by waves, actually shutters. Even a good
breath of wind will do it if you sit real still
and keep your mouth shut. Notched to certain
center, it yields, then comes back to it. Wobbly
ton. Imagine seeing the spore of a good kachunk,
kachunk. And one of the things I did in his,
you know, thing I wrote on his perception
exercises, you know, spiritual exercises, is
this teaches impermanence. The Buddhists say
everything is impermanent. What's more permanent
than a rock? Rock solid, permanent, but the rock
itself is going to picture it. So this gets deep
into your bones, the sense that all has. And
so anyway, in that poem, he has a riddle,
and it says, riddle me a riddle, *Dychymyg, dychymyg*.
That's Welsh for riddle me a riddle. Waves in the sea,
if you take away the sea, tell me what it is.
Well, it took me a long time to solve that one,
but I realized that if you have waves in the
sea and take away the sea, you have waves and
without the sea, you know. And so that's in the realm of language, waves and,
which is the same thing as saying wave sand. And
then, so what the answer is, waves in the sea,
if you take away the sea, tell me what it is.
You know when you're walking on a beach and the
tide is going out and you see these little
ripples, they're left by the tide as it went out,
they're sort of dried now and they're like little
ridges. And that's what it is. It's the ripples
left by the retreating sea and drying sand.
So look, it's both there in the actual world.
It's not, you know, well waves represent energy or
motion and the sea is the enveloping metaphysical
matrix. No, waves in the sea, you take away
the waves, there are the waves, but they're not
moving. You know, they're in the sand, they're in
the drying sand. So this is something that you can
perceive in the world, which has profound
metaphysical implications. You just don't start
from the conceptual, you start from the existential, from the physical. And at the
same time, it has to do with life. You know, you
take away waves and you want to be very literal
about it. Waves and the sea take away the sea,
okay. You know, so that's the kind of mind that
he felt correctly was almost unique to him. I
mean, he saw and learned something I haven't
found anywhere else. So that's why I figured
that if I turned those into, you know, Buddhist
exercises and sent them to Peter Coyote, he
would accept them. And he did hear, he said,
you know, you're right. And he's going to be
teaching them to his students, you know. And
so I told him the answer to Lew Welch's two
riddles, because he was, I wasn't supposed to
do that. Because Lew had these two riddles, he
said, in every religion, every place and time,
there's been a gesture of bowing, you know, so,
forget how it was, so fully that the forehead
strikes the ground. Why is this? And he says,
there's only one right answer to this riddle.
It's not a koan, because koan can have innumerable right answers, depending upon
the state of the answer. But this is the one right answer. And the other one was,
in every religion, every place and time, there's
been a gesture of the hands clasped as if in
prayer. Why is this? And he told me the answer
to the first one, and I solved the second one by
myself. And it's basically, it isn't conceptual,
it's entirely concrete and physical, and it's
nothing to do with religion or metaphysics.
But once you solve it, then you see the amazing
symbolic resonance that you can go to town
on metaphysics from if you want to, you know,
but you can't start with the conceptual. The
conceptual is the echo. It's not, you know,
what you have to do is you drop the rock first in
the pool. The rock is very concrete and blocked.
Then the waves of conceptual understanding
spread, but you've got to drop the rock first.
And that's, so anyway, those two riddles, I told both of them to Peter Coyote because
he was going to teach him, so we had to know.
But I haven't told him anybody else, nor will I.
So the answer to the second riddle was confirmed by Magda after he
passed on, because she solved it when I think she was in. She was in Latin America,
in South America at the time, seeking out the
shaman that William Burroughs and Allen Ginsburg
had gone to to find yagé or Ayahuasca. This was
before Ayahuasca was very big in the counterculture,
but she was going around the world finding new drugs. So she was down there, you know,
and she actually bought Ayahuasca, one of the
first to bring Ayahuasca back to the United States,
which I can say now because she's no longer with
us. And so which is why when Huey Lewis came out
with his song, I Need a New Drug, we all said, you
know, if the stuff that Magda brought back from
around the world, Ibogaine from Africa and all this
stuff, you know, if that doesn't do it for him,
nothing will. So that's the kind of stuff he taught, both verbally and in terms of,
basically in terms of what Zen is trying to do with a different approach.
That poem by Gary Snyder, I know was from a
dream. You know, Lew Welch just turned up one day,
why was he with me? Damn, well, you didn't die
after all. I said, you know, yes, I did, he said,
even then I could feel, you know, because Snyder
is one of the greatest dream poets. I mean,
he's got just some, you know, some of his best poems are straight out of dream.
Did Lew Welch consider himself a Zen practitioner of any kind?
Well, those guys sort of all did, like, like the hippies considered themselves,
yogis or, you know, it was the people who got
serious about, well, Gary Snyder was more serious.
And so, and Philip Whelan, those were the three
guys that knew each other at Reed College,
Philip Whelan, Gary Snyder and Lew Welch. So Gary
Snyder, who I guess is still alive up there in
Tennessee, yeah, 92 or 93. And, you know,
basically, he, as I understand, has been running
a very formal Zendo up there. But Philip Whelan
actually was ordained as a Zen priest and
worked out of the San Francisco Zen Center for a while. So, but other, you know,
he, Lew was more like Kerouac. Kerouac never
joined anything. But he wrote some amazing
Buddhist scripture, you know, the scripture of the Golden Eternity is
worthy of being considered a Buddhist sutra.
And it's truly, it's not, it's not just,
he was very serious about that. And so, you know,
Lew was, but Lew was trying everything because
he was trying to kick, you know, the drinking
habit. And, I mean, I get the idea, there are
probably people who know this better than I
do, you know, but I get the idea he did, he did
psychotherapy, he did Gurdjieff work. He did,
I think even what the Scientology once to see,
to get clear. And, but, you know, to see if he could save his life. But generally,
and, you know, I know it's like Alan Watts,
you could include it in this characterization,
generally that generation, if they had a default religion, it was Zen Buddhism.
You know, some of them were more serious than others.
Well, Alan Watts, I think, was also, if not an
alcoholic himself, a very heavy drinker. And
the use and abuse of drugs was also part and parcel of the Beat Movement.
Well, yeah, I mean, Ginsburg tried all sorts of drugs before anybody else.
He wrote some great poems. I mean, he had a poem,
Life Surgic Acid, I don't know if that was LSD or
some other version of LSD. He had a poem, Ether,
which, you know, Ether is a, these are drugs,
which were talked about by William James in Varieties of the Religious Experience.
And so, Ginsburg's poem, Ether, is an amazing tour de force. I mean, I've never,
you just want to see the mind going through all, I mean, it's so lucid and so amazing,
you know. And then he has got a great poem from LSD, Whales Visitation, lovely poem.
But he, you know, he was, you know, take
different drugs and see what they do and write.
You know, Timothy Leary was doing it under more
controlled conditions, although I don't know
how controlled they really were. But, you know,
the idea was you need to set them a setting and,
you know, slightly more laboratory conditions,
if you will. Whereas Kesey just says,
put it in the punch, everybody take it to
the party, wham, wham, you know. But I think
there was an idea that if you spread these drugs
out to everybody, you can break down the old
paradigms of church, family, political
identification, this. And then the population
becomes, you know, a plastic substance, formless plastic substance that the
social engineers can mold into what form they
wish. Some people, at least, were thinking it,
this is a form that goes back to the Fabian
socialists. The Fabian socialists were gradualist
revolutionaries. They would basically say, okay,
you know, you inflamed the proletariat, you kept
them going, they overthrow the czar, you know,
they set up a, you know, a Soviet state and do
this and do this. But then there's all this
reaction and, you know, and it hasn't really
penetrated. It's been imposed upon people. So they
haven't accepted it themselves. It's been imposed
on them, you know. So it's unstable and it can
fall apart. And it did, of course, it did. So
the Fabian socialist idea was take generations
to generation. They can sit there and say,
this generation will do this, the generation
after that will have this rule, the generation
after that. It's hard for us to imagine that people could be so serious about
consciously transforming society without society's
knowledge. But I believe that that such is the
case. And, you know, I think that, you know,
the use of psychedelics was one big step.
Well, we've covered a lot of ground, Charles.
Let me ask you this question to get back to the
Beat Generation. Now we can look back at it with
the perspective of decades. What do you think was
the impact of that group of writers, Lew Welch
and Gary Snyder and Allen Ginsberg and the others?
Basically, Ginsberg, Kerouac and Burroughs were
the ones who had the most impact. And it was vast.
I mean, it gave a template for the hippies to
connect with and do their own thing, which was
so much more extensive, you know, larger numbers
than the Beats. And, well, it's not the same
nation as it was in 1958. Everything changed. Everything changed. And, you know,
some for the better, a lot for the worse.
You know, I mean, I wouldn't say, oh, if only
something hadn't happened because it was going
to have. You know, we're getting to the end
of this cycle of manifestation on Earth. That's
pretty clear. Look, any direction you want to
look in, you see something coming to an end. Now,
I'm not saying that no humans will survive on
Earth. I'm saying all the structures that have
been made, and not just Western civilization,
but every civilization worth the name for thousands and thousands of years are ending
right now. And this was one of the phases. And so
you say, well, it was terrible because it broke
down the society we need, you know, because
human beings can't live without a viable society,
even if it has problems, even if it is
narrow-minded in some ways. You know, is chaos,
total chaos really better? You don't have to say that. You can also say,
given that it was going to break down anyway,
these doors were opened to the possibility
of seeing something beyond the cycles of time.
So you could let the apocalypse do its thing.
And part of you is already beyond it. Part of you is, you know, in touch with higher
consciousness and with higher realities. So
some bit of the human substance can survive,
you know, the end of things, you know, and possibly reseed the world, the human world,
because, you know, I wouldn't have done my Sufism and all the people who got involved
in mystical spiritualities and all of the developments in psychology and whatever you
talk about, and parapsychology. You know, this
wouldn't have happened without the counterculture.
It would have been small groups that would not have had much of an effect on society.
But, you know, now let's learn in those groups, for good or bad, for good or ill,
it's had a massive effect on society. And so,
you know, let those, you know, who can catch
the higher transmission, what didn't come through
all of that, you know, more power to them and let
them go all the way with it. And because there's
nothing else that's going to fit us to face what
we have to face on this earth, then, you know,
consciousness of higher worlds, which, you know,
it was only a little mystic here and there. It was a Meister Eckhart or somebody else,
you know, but there's nothing to lose. Somewhere
it was said, look, there's nothing to lose.
Open all the doors for everybody, even if 80% of what comes through them is demons.
Open because it's going to be open anyway,
so we've got to be a little ahead of the game
and get ready, you know, to deal with the vast
changes that are coming. So, you know, I don't,
I say, I can criticize it, I can say this is
the evil that came out of the counterculture,
but I don't say, you know, it never should have
happened because, you know, like the Catholics say,
the Muslims say it's all God's will, you know, and
he's, you know, what the Quran says beautifully,
succinctly, it says, there is no refuge from God
but in him. Because if you're in the periphery of
things, you know, involved in circumstances
and, you know, the changing scenes of history,
which are changing at the speed of light now,
you know, you're going to be beaten to the pulp,
you know, and that's the judgment of God. Whereas
if you get into the center from where it's all
coming from, and you get what T.S. Eliot called
the still point of the turning world, which is,
the simple symbol of that or the physical manifestation of that is the polar star,
you know, in the sky around which all the stars
turn. If you can get there, then all is mercy,
and all is salvation. But it's the same energy.
It's very hard to go closer to the thing that's
causing all this pain when you're out on the
periphery. It hurts so much out there, you want
to go closer to where it's coming from? Yeah,
that's the idea. It's the only thing you can do.
And you go closer, and you finally get to a place
where it transforms from judgment and suffering
into mercy and healing and light. And I mean,
there's nothing like LSD in the future that lesson,
you know. And I hate to quote Jim Morrison in a
time like this, because he was a pretty sinister
guy in many ways. But he said, you know, try to
run, try to hide, break on through to the other
side. So if we learn anything from LSD, it was,
you know, go toward the source of the pain,
go right toward it, and there will be a moment
where you get through. So that wasn't enough.
You got to learn how to go toward it. So I was just taking a pill, but, you know,
so it wasn't all evil. Well, Charles Upton, what a magnificent discourse. Thank you.
